19 
INTRODUCTION 
20 
  Edward Byrne Memorial Justice Assistance Grant (“Byrne JAG”) program funds have 
21 
been the focal point of an ongoing dispute between the federal, state, and local governments for 
22 
the past two years.  After President Trump assumed office, he issued an Executive Order 
23 
announcing a policy of withholding federal grants from “sanctuary jurisdictions,” which was 
24 
challenged by the City and County of San Francisco and the County of Santa Clara.  I granted 
25 
summary judgment to prevent the Executive Order from being enforced; the Ninth Circuit 
26 
affirmed.  City and Cty. of San Francisco v. Trump, 275 F. Supp. 3d 1196 (N.D. Cal. 2017), aff’d 
27 
in part, vacated in part, remanded sub nom. City and Cty. of San Francisco v. Trump, 897 F.3d 
28 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 2 of 31
 
1  1225 (9th Cir. 2018). 
2  Shortly thereafter, former Attorney General Jefferson Beauregard Sessions III imposed 
3  three new conditions on the receipt of Byrne JAG funding for fiscal year 2017: the access, notice, 
4  and Section 1373 certification conditions.  These conditions required Byrne JAG applicants to 
5  provide Immigration and Customs Enforcement (“ICE”) with “access” to correctional facilities for 
6  immigration enforcement purposes, “notice” of detainee release dates, and to certify compliance 
7  with 8 U.S.C. § 1373.  California and San Francisco sued the DOJ for withholding their fiscal year 
8  2017 grant funds after they asserted compliance with the new conditions.  I found that the 
9  challenged conditions were unlawful on multiple grounds and held that Section 1373 was 
10  unconstitutional.  City & Cty. of San Francisco v. Sessions, 349 F. Supp. 3d 924, 934 (N.D. Cal. 
11  2018), judgment entered sub nom. California ex rel. Becerra v. Sessions, No. 3:17-CV-04701-
a  12  WHO, 2018 WL 6069940 (N.D. Cal. Nov. 20, 2018). 
rt ni
ur
oo 13    For fiscal year 2018, defendants Acting Attorney General Matthew G. Whitaker and the 
Cif
t al
icC 14  Department of Justice (collectively, the “DOJ”) continued to include essentially the same fiscal 
strof 
Dict  15  year 2017 challenged conditions as well as two other new conditions.  The additional 2018 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  conditions require Byrne JAG recipients: (i) not to publicly disclose sensitive federal law 
d Srn 
ee 17  enforcement information in an attempt to harbor or shield “fugitives from justice” or “aliens” in 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  violation of federal immigration law (the “nondisclosure condition”); and (ii) to provide 
19  information about the applicant’s laws and policies for purposes of assessing compliance with 
20  Section 1373 (the “information condition”).  
21    California and San Francisco have sued the DOJ challenging five conditions in the fiscal 
22  year 2018 Byrne JAG Program.  The DOJ filed a partial motion to dismiss or a partial motion for 
23  summary judgment, seeking dismissal or judgment on California’s and San Francisco’s claims 
24  regarding the nondisclosure and information conditions.  The DOJ has preserved its arguments on 
25  the access, notice, and certification conditions from the prior case on fiscal year 2017 funds, which 
26  apply to some of the fiscal year 2018 Byrne JAG funding.  
27  California and San Francisco responded with their own motions for summary judgment.  
28  They seek declaratory relief that the challenged conditions are unconstitutional violations of the 
2 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 3 of 31
 
1  separation of powers and the Spending Clause of the United States Constitution and to enjoin the 
2  DOJ from enforcing the challenged conditions or withholding Byrne JAG funds based on those 
3  requirements.  California also brings an Administrative Procedure Act claim and seeks mandamus 
4  relief compelling the DOJ to issue California its fiscal year 2018 Byrne JAG awards without the 
5  challenged conditions. 
6  Only the nondisclosure condition raises a substantive concern that I have not addressed, 
7  and it fails for somewhat different reasons than the other conditions.  Left to its core—that local 
8  jurisdictions should not publicize confidential federal law enforcement actions that are disclosed to 
9  local authorities to insure deconfliction and protect local law enforcement and residents—seems 
10  self-evident and reasonable.  But DOJ did not leave it to its core, and instead larded it with broad-
11  ranging, ambiguous language that would allow DOJ the discretion to coerce local jurisdictions to 
a  12  comply with its interpretation of the statutes in dispute in these cases.  The exercise of such 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  discretion is all the more suspect in light of the active litigation over immigration issues between 
Cif
t al
icC 14  California jurisdictions and the federal government, and the threat made by Administration 
strof 
Dict  15  officials to commence criminal prosecution of California officials who follow that sovereign’s 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  interpretation of the law.  See, e.g., CA Request for Judicial Notice (“RJN”), Ex. F (DHS 
d Srn 
ee 17  Secretary Nielsen confirming to the Senate Judiciary Committee that DOJ was “reviewing what 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  avenues might be available” to bring criminal charges against elected officials abiding by 
19  sanctuary policies.). 
20  Accordingly, for the reasons discussed more fully below, I find that (i) the challenged 
21  conditions are ultra vires and violate the separation of powers, (ii) Section 1373 is 
22  unconstitutional, (iii) the Attorney General exceeds the Spending Clause in violation of the United 
23  States Constitution by imposing ambiguous challenged conditions in the fiscal year 2018 Byrne 
24  JAG Program, (iv) the conditions are arbitrary and capricious, (v) California is entitled to the 
25  mandamus relief it seeks, and (vi) a nationwide injunction is warranted but stayed.  California’s 
26  and San Francisco’s motions for summary judgment are granted, and the DOJ’s motions are 
27  denied. 
28   
3 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 4 of 31
 
1  BACKGROUND 
2  I.  FACTUAL BACKGROUND 
3  A.  The Immigration and Nationality Act 
4  Congress reinforced the Executive Branch’s inherent authority “over the subject of 
5  immigration and the status of aliens” when it passed the Immigration and Nationality Act (“INA”), 
6  8 U.S.C.  § 1101 et seq.  Arizona v. United States, 567 U.S. 387, 394 (2012).  The INA authorizes 
7  the Department of Homeland Security (“DHS”) as well as the DOJ and other federal agencies to 
8  enforce the immigration laws.  See, e.g., 8 U.S.C. § 1227(a)(2) (allowing the Attorney General or 
9  Secretary of Homeland Security to order removal of certain classes of immigrants).  It also 
10  contemplates coordination between federal officials and state or local jurisdictions.  See Arizona, 
11  567 U.S. at 411 (“Consultation between federal and state officials is an important feature of the 
a  12  immigration system.”).  Various provisions seek to accomplish such coordination and information 
rt ni
ouor 13  sharing when possible.  See 8 U.S.C. § 1252c (authorizing state and local officers to make arrests 
Cif
t al
icC 14  for unlawful reentry); 8 U.S.C. § 1324(c) (authorizing state and local officers to make arrests for 
strof 
Dict  15  INA violations); 8 U.S.C. § 1357(g) (authorizing state and local officers to perform functions of a 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  federal immigration officer). 
d Srn 
ee 17  B.  The Byrne JAG Program 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  The Byrne JAG program is a formula grant program that is administered by the Bureau of 
19  Justice Assistance, a department within the Office of Justice Programs (“OJP”).  See 34 U.S.C. § 
20  10156(d)(2)(A) (stating that “the Attorney General shall allocate to each unit of local government” 
21  funds determined by the established formula).  Grant funding is awarded as a function of 
22  population and violent crime rate.  See 34 U.S.C. § 10156(a).  Eligible grantees are entitled to their 
23  awards so long as their Byrne JAG funds go toward programs in one of eight program areas: (1) 
24  law enforcement, (2) prosecution and court, (3) prevention and education, (4) corrections and 
25  community corrections, (5) drug treatment and enforcement, (6) planning, evaluation, and 
26  technology improvement, (7) crime victim and witness programs, and (8) mental health programs.  
27  See 34 U.S.C. § 10152(a)(1)(A)–(H).  
28  Under the formula, California is expected to receive $28.9 million Byrne JAG funds in 
4 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 5 of 31
 
1  fiscal year 2018, including $18 million going to the Board of State and Community Corrections 
2  (“BSCC”).  Jolls Decl. ¶ 5.  The BSCC plans to continue using the funds for education and crime 
3  prevention, law enforcement, and court programs, as it has in previous years.  Id. ¶¶ 9–10 
4  (detailing the types of sub-grants that BSCC has provided in previous years, and the focus on 
5  education and crime prevention programs for the next three-year grant cycle). 
6  San Francisco is expected to receive $489,966 in direct Byrne JAG funding and 
7  approximately $1 million in state sub-grant funding under the formula.  Chyi Decl. ¶ 8, Ex. C.  
8  San Francisco uses the funding to support law enforcement programs aimed at reducing the drug 
9  trade and recidivism among repeat offenders, and for programs connecting those with substance 
10  and mental health problems to appropriate services.  Id. ¶¶ 10–11, 17.  As in fiscal year 2017, San 
11  Francisco faces the prospect of eliminating approximately ten full-time positions spanning six 
a  12  departments without Byrne JAG funding.  Id. ¶¶ 10–19; see also City & Cty. of San Francisco, 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  349 F. Supp. 3d at 936 (discussing San Francisco’s intended uses for JAG funds).  
Cif
t al
icC 14  California and San Francisco received their fiscal year 2018 Byrne JAG award documents 
strof 
Dict  15  on November 16, 2018.  See DOJ RJN Exs. C, D.1  Because the award documents contained the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  challenged conditions at issue in this litigation, California and San Francisco requested and 
d Srn 
ee 17  received an extension from the DOJ to accept the awards until 30 days after a Judgment is entered 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  in their respective cases.  Chyi Decl. ¶ 15–16; Sherman Decl. at Ex. 7.  
19  C.  Fiscal Year 2017 Byrne JAG Program Conditions and Related Litigation 
20  In 2016, the DOJ announced that Section 1373 would be an “applicable law” for the Byrne 
21  JAG Program.  See Admin. Record (“AR”)-384 (SF Dkt. No. 26; CA Dkt. No. 24).  For the 
22  following fiscal year (2017), the Byrne JAG Solicitation formalized the announcement, requiring a 
23 
                                                 
1 The parties requested judicial notice of various public records, government documents, or court 
24 
filings, whose accuracy and authenticity are not disputed.  Government records such as letters, 
memos, bulletins, or other reports or statements of public record are judicially noticeable.  See, 
25 
e.g., Brown v. Valoff, 422 F.3d 926, 933 n.9 (9th Cir. 2005) (taking judicial notice of government 
administrative bulletin); Fed. R. Evid. 201(b).  Court records from other proceedings are also 
26 
susceptible to judicial notice if relevant to this litigation.  See U.S. ex rel. Robinson Rancheria 
Citizens Council v. Borneo, Inc., 971 F.2d 244, 248 (9th Cir. 1992) (holding that a court “may take 
27 
notice of proceedings in other courts, both within and without the federal judicial system, if those 
proceedings have a direct relation to matters at issue”).  Thus, the requests for judicial notice are 
28 
GRANTED.  See SF Dkt. Nos. 27-1, 31, 57; CA Dkt. Nos. 25-1, 29-2, 41-1, 45.   
5 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 6 of 31
 
1  certification of compliance with Section 1373.  AR-994, 1032-33.  The DOJ additionally required 
2  Byrne JAG funding recipients to have policies allowing federal agents “access” to any state or 
3  local government correctional facility, and to provide “notice” of scheduled release dates for non-
4  citizens in those facilities.  AR-1687–88. 
5  I found, along with every court to hear challenges to the fiscal year 2017 Byrne JAG 
6  conditions, that these conditions were unlawful.  See City & Cty. of San Francisco, 349 F. Supp. 
7  3d at 940–41 (summarizing related litigation at the time concerning the fiscal year 2017 Byrne 
8  JAG conditions); see also City of Chicago v. Sessions, 888 F.3d 272, 293 (7th Cir. 2018) 
9  (invalidating notice and access conditions); City of Philadelphia v. Sessions, 309 F. Supp. 3d 289 
10  (E.D. Pa. 2018) (invalidating the notice, access, and Section 1373 certification condition). 
11  Since then, the Third Circuit has affirmed in part the City of Philadelphia decision.  City of 
a  12  Philadelphia v. Attorney Gen. of United States of Am., No. 18-2648, 2019 WL 638931 (3d Cir. 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  Feb. 15, 2019).  The court found that no authority was conferred to the DOJ by Congress via the 
Cif
t al
icC 14  Byrne JAG statute itself or other statutes at issue here such as Section 10102 or Section 
strof 
Dict  15  10153(a)(5)(D).  Id. at *10.  Several more courts also found the 2017 challenged conditions 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  unlawful.  In States of New York, et al. v. Dep't of Justice, 343 F. Supp. 3d 213 (S.D.N.Y. 2018), 
d Srn 
ee 17  the court granted plaintiffs’ motion for partial summary judgment.  It found the 2017 conditions 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  were ultra vires under the Administrative Procedure Act (“APA”), id. at 231, Section 1373 was 
19  unconstitutional under the anticommandeering doctrine of the Tenth Amendment, id. at 237, the 
20  conditions violated the separation of powers, id. at 238, and the conditions were arbitrary and 
21  capricious under the APA, id. at 241.  Similarly, in Los Angeles v. Sessions, No. 17-cv-7215 (C.D. 
22  Cal. Sept. 13, 2018) (Dkt. No. 93) the court granted plaintiff’s motion for preliminary injunction 
23  of the 2017 challenged conditions.  It found that 34 U.S.C. § 10153(a), the provision providing the 
24  Attorney General with authority over the “form” of the application, did not indicate authority to 
25  add civil immigration conditions.  Id. at 3.   
26  In City of Los Angeles v. Sessions, No. 18-cv-7347 (C.D. Cal. Feb. 15, 2019), the district 
27  court addressed the same fiscal year 2018 Byrne JAG conditions at issue here and granted 
28  plaintiff’s motion for summary judgment while denying defendant’s motion for partial dismissal 
6 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 7 of 31
 
1  or partial summary judgment.  See Joint Supp. RJN, Ex. A.  It found no authority conferred by 
2  Section 10153(a)(5)(D) to support the nondisclosure condition, and it found that the information 
3  condition exceeded the “programmatic and financial information” that the Attorney General was 
4  otherwise authorized to require of state and local governments.  Id. at 7–8.  Lastly, the court 
5  granted a program-wide injunction and permanently enjoined the defendants from imposing the 
6  challenged conditions in fiscal year 2018 Byrne JAG awards.  Id. at 10.  
7  D.  Challenged Conditions in the Fiscal Year 2018 Byrne JAG Program 
8  The DOJ continued to utilize requirements that are functionally equivalent to the three 
9  challenged conditions in the prior fiscal year 2017 JAG Solicitation and added two new conditions 
10  in fiscal year 2018.  California and San Francisco challenge each of these five conditions in the 
11  2018 Byrne JAG Solicitation.  See SF First Amended Compl. (“FAC”) (Dkt. No. 22); CA FAC 
a  12  (Dkt. No. 20).  The DOJ moves for partial dismissal or summary judgment on the two new 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  conditions.  
Cif
t al
icC 14  The 2018 Solicitation requires California and San Francisco, through their chief legal 
strof 
Dict  15  officer, to continue to certify compliance with Section 1373.  It modifies this requirement 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  somewhat by also requiring certification of compliance with 8 U.S.C. § 1644.  See DOJ RJN Ex. 
d Srn 
ee 17  D ¶¶ 41–43.  Section 1644 contains nearly identical language as Section 1373 and prohibits 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  restrictions on communicating immigration information.  AR-1258, 1264.   
19  The 2018 Solicitation also requires the chief legal officer to certify that the applying 
20  jurisdiction will not interfere with law enforcement in their access to correctional facilities or in 
21  the removal process by failing to provide notice of scheduled release dates and times.  See DOJ 
22  RJN Ex. D ¶¶ 45–46.  Put another way, the Solicitation requires the applicant not to have laws, 
23  policies, or practices that “impede” federal officers from exercising their authority under 8 U.S.C. 
24  § 1357(a) and which impede their authority “relating to” 8 U.S.C. §§ 1226(a), 1226(c), 1231(a)(4), 
25  1366(1), and 1366(3).  AR-1233, 1241–42, 1250, 1260, 1268.  Section 1357(a) describes 
26  immigration officer authority to “interrogate any alien,” “arrest any alien,” or exercise other 
27  proscribed powers without a warrant.  8 U.S.C. § 1357(a).  Additionally, Sections 1226, 1231, and 
28  1366 involve immigration officer powers to make arrests, detain, and release undocumented 
7 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 8 of 31
 
1  persons, and to make annual reports on certain “criminal alien” statistics. 
2  The nondisclosure and the information conditions appear for the first time in the fiscal year 
3  2018 Byrne JAG funding conditions.  The nondisclosure condition provides that:  
 
4 
Consistent with the purposes and objectives of federal law enforcement statutes and 
federal criminal law (including 8 U.S.C. 1324 and 18 U.S.C. chs. 1, 49, 227), no public 
5 
disclosure may be made of any federal law enforcement information in a direct or 
6  indirect attempt to conceal, harbor, or shield from detection any fugitive from justice 
under 18 U.S.C. ch. 49, or any alien who has come to, entered, or remains in the United 
7  States in violation of 8 U.S.C. ch. 12 – without regard to whether such disclosure would 
constitute (or could form a predicate for) a violation of 18 U.S.C. 1071 or 1072 or of 8 
8  U.S.C. 1324(a).  
9  See DOJ RJN Ex. D ¶ 44.  
10  The information condition, which the DOJ disputes is a condition in the first instance, 
11  requires award recipients to collect certain information from sub-grant recipients.  Id., Ex. D ¶ 47.  
a  12  For example, California would not be able to authorize a sub-grant “unless it first obtains from the 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  proposed subrecipient responses to the questions identified in the program solicitation as 
Cif
t al
icC 14  ‘Information regarding Communication with the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) and/or 
strof 
Dict  15  Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE).”  Id.  Those questions include whether the 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  jurisdiction has “any laws, policies, or practices related to whether, when, or how employees may 
d Srn 
ee 17  communicate with DHS or ICE,” and require applicants to provide a copy of the law or policy, 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  describe the practices, and explain how it complies with Section 1373.  See FAC at 52 (SF Dkt. 
19  No. 22-2; CA Dkt. No. 20-1). 
20  E.  California and San Francisco’s Laws and Policies 
21  The plaintiffs’ asserted interests implicated by the Byrne JAG Program challenged 
22  conditions have been discussed thoroughly in the prior litigation of the fiscal year 2017 conditions.  
23  See City & Cty. of San Francisco, 349 F. Supp. 3d at 937–40 (summarizing California and San 
24  Francisco laws and policies relevant to the 2017 conditions).  The California Legislature sought, in 
25  its laws and policies, to use its “limited resources for public safety rather than immigration 
26  enforcement” after concluding that limited involvement with immigration enforcement resulted in 
27  safer communities.  Id. at 938 (citing Cal. Gov. Code § 7284.2(f)).  It also based policies on local 
28  law enforcement’s belief in the importance of maintaining trust with immigrant communities.  Id.  
8 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 9 of 31
 
1  San Francisco agreed, providing its own evidence in support of the importance that trust holds for 
2  “greater reporting of crimes, more cooperative witnesses, and more assistance with law 
3  enforcement investigations.”  Id. at 941. 
4  II.  PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND 
5  In August 2018, California and San Francisco filed lawsuits challenging the DOJ’s 
6  imposition of the five challenged conditions on Byrne JAG funding in fiscal year 2018.  See 
7  Complaint (SF Dkt. No. 1; CA Dkt. No. 1).  The plaintiffs filed their first amended complaints in 
8  November 2018, and the DOJ filed a motion for partial dismissal or partial summary judgment in 
9  December.  See DOJ Partial Mot. to Dismiss or Summ. J. (SF Dkt. No. 27; CA Dkt. No. 25).  In 
10  response, California and San Francisco filed motions for summary judgment.  See Mots. For 
11  Summ. J. (SF Dkt. No. 30; CA Dkt. No. 29).  Amici have also filed briefs in both matters.2  
a  12  LEGAL STANDARD 
rt ni
ur
oo 13  I.  MOTIONS TO DISMISS 
Cif
t al
icC 14  To survive a Rule 12(b)(6) motion to dismiss, the plaintiff must allege “enough facts to 
strof 
Dict  15  state a claim to relief that is plausible on its face.”  Bell Atl. Corp. v. Twombly, 550 U.S. 544, 570 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  (2007).  A claim is plausible when the plaintiff pleads facts that “allow[] the court to draw the 
d Srn 
ee 17  reasonable inference that the defendant is liable for the misconduct alleged.”  Ashcroft v. Iqbal, 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  556 U.S. 662, 678 (2009) (citation omitted).  While courts do not require “heightened fact 
19  pleading of specifics,” a plaintiff must allege facts sufficient to “raise a right to relief above the 
20  speculative level.”  Twombly, 550 U.S. at 555, 570.  There must be “more than a sheer possibility 
21  that a defendant has acted unlawfully.”  Id. 
22  To decide if the plaintiff has stated a claim upon which relief can be granted, the court 
23  accepts the plaintiff’s allegations as true and draws all reasonable inferences in favor of the 
24  plaintiff.  See Usher v. City of Los Angeles, 828 F.2d 556, 561 (9th Cir. 1987).  However, the court 
25  is not required to accept as true “allegations that are merely conclusory, unwarranted deductions of 
26 
                                                 
27 
2 There are two motions for leave to file amicus briefs.  See Admin. Mots. for Leave (SF Dkt. No. 
54; CA Dkt. No. 38).  Because each motion complies with my prior Order Regarding Amicus 
28 
Briefing, they are GRANTED.  
9 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 10 of 31
 
1  fact, or unreasonable inferences.”  In re Gilead Scis. Sec. Litig., 536 F.3d 1049, 1055 (9th Cir. 
2  2008). 
3  If the court dismisses a complaint, it “should grant leave to amend even if no request to 
4  amend the pleading was made, unless it determines that the pleading could not possibly be cured 
5  by the allegation of other facts.”  Lopez v. Smith, 203 F.3d 1122, 1127 (9th Cir. 2000).  In making 
6  this determination, the court should consider factors such as “the presence or absence of undue 
7  delay, bad faith, dilatory motive, repeated failure to cure deficiencies by previous amendments, 
8  undue prejudice to the opposing party and futility of the proposed amendment.”  Moore v. Kayport 
9  Package Express, 885 F.2d 531, 538 (9th Cir. 1989). 
10  II.  MOTIONS FOR SUMMARY JUDGMENT  
11  A party is entitled to summary judgment where it “shows that there is no genuine dispute 
a  12  as to any material fact and [it] is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.”  FED. R. CIV. P. 56(a).  
rt ni
ur
oo 13  To prevail, a party moving for summary judgment must show the lack of a genuine issue of 
Cif
t al
icC 14  material fact with respect to an essential element of the non-moving party’s claim, or to a defense 
strof 
Dict  15  on which the non-moving party will bear the burden of persuasion at trial.  See Celotex Corp. v. 
s ri
et
tatDis 16  Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 323 (1986).  Once the movant has made this showing, the burden then shifts 
d Srn 
ee 17  to the party opposing summary judgment to identify “specific facts showing there is a genuine 
th
nirt
Uo
N 18  issue for trial.”  Id.  The party opposing summary judgment must then present affirmative 
19  evidence from which a jury could return a verdict in that party’s favor.  Anderson v. Liberty 
20  Lobby, 477 U.S. 242, 257 (1986). 
21  On summary judgment, the Court draws all reasonable factual inferences in favor of the 
22  non-movant.  Id. at 255.  In deciding a motion for summary judgment, “[c]redibility 
23  determinations, the weighing of the evidence, and the drawing of legitimate inferences from the 
24  facts are jury functions, not those of a judge.”  Id.  However, conclusory and speculative testimony 
25  does not raise genuine issues of fact and is insufficient to defeat summary judgment.  See 
26  Thornhill Publ’g Co., Inc. v. GTE Corp., 594 F.2d 730, 738 (9th Cir. 1979).

19  The DOJ moves to dismiss or for summary judgment on California’s arbitrary and 
20  capricious APA claim.  It asserts that the claim fails because its reasons for imposing the condition 
21  and requirements “were entirely rational.”  FCC v. Fox Television Stations, Inc., 556 U.S. 502, 
22  517 (2009).  The DOJ insists that it was reasonable for the Office of Justice Programs to deny 
23  federal law enforcement funding to a jurisdiction that publicly discloses sensitive information in 
24  an attempt to harbor unlawful immigrants or fugitives from detection, or for refusing to provide 
25  information about its laws or policies on communicating with federal authorities.  
26  In APA claims asserting that agency action was “arbitrary, capricious, an abuse of 
27  discretion, or otherwise not in accordance with law,” 5 U.S.C. § 706(2)(A), the defendant agency 
28  is required to “examine the relevant data and articulate a satisfactory explanation” for their 
25 

Case 3:18-cv-05169-WHO   Document 47   Filed 03/04/19   Page 26 of 31
 
1  actions.  Motor Vehicle Mfrs. Ass’n of U.S., Inc. v. State Farm Mut. Auto. Ins. Co., 463 U.S. 29, 43 
2  (1983).  Actions with a “rational connection between the facts found and the choice made” are 
3  valid.  Id.  In contrast, agency action should be overturned if the agency relied on factors Congress 
4  did not intend for it to consider, failed to consider important aspects of the problem, or its decision 
5  was counter to the evidence before it.  Id.  Thus, the reviewing court should “not supply a 
6  reasoned basis for the agency’s action that the agency itself has not given,” and should “uphold a 
7  decision of less than ideal clarity if the agency’s path may reasonably be discerned.”  Bowman 
8  Transp., Inc. v. Arkansas-Best Freight Sys., Inc., 419 U.S. 281, 285–86 (1974) (internal citation 
9  omitted).
